As per expectation, the stunts are stunning, the suits are a spectacle and the story reaches audacious comic book proportions, but the driving force and key factor behind the Iron Man franchise success remains Robert Downey Jr. With his offbeat personality, self-deprecating humor, likeable presence, bang on comic timing and new found brawniness, Downey's approachable edginess sideswipes the fast-paced graphic heavy handedness to find purchase and once again smash Box Office Records.

Mentally suffering the effects of his encounter with aliens and otherworldly forces (yes, The Avengers) , our "only a human man with a suit" superhero Tony Stark (Robert Downey Jr) is all consumed by his work, losing touch with the outside world, incapable of sleep and pushing away the affections of his now live-in girlfriend Pepper Pots (Gwyneth Paltrow).

When a new merciless Bin Laden inspired baddie, known from his menacing broadcasts as the Mandarin (a memorable for all the right reasons, Ben Kingsley) captures his undivided attention, the irritated Stark willingly offers his home address (aka engineering lab and fortress) as a public challenge. The invitation for a showdown is met leaving his personal and professional world in ruins.

Perceived dead, Stark must embark on a treacherous and harrowing quest for retribution to regain his life. Relying solely on his own devices, ingenuity and instinct, he must protect both the 'one he can't live without and the President of United States and stop the Mandarins reign of terror. 

The key lies in uncovering the source behind a series of mysterious explosions that lack a detonation device, obviously connected somehow it highlights a new player in the endgame, or is it just an old discard of Stark's now demanding his attention. 

In the end, as per all comics, there is always a moral to the story that secretly haunts the main character, and Iron Man is no different: does the man make the suit or does the suit make the man? 

Balancing our dynamic superhero with some key one liners, is the perfectly manicured and impressively buffed Guy Pearce as DNA tampering Aldrich Killian, and proving the conduit for some emotional depth is talented youngster Ty Simpkins in the role of Harley (also giving Downey a run for his smart alec money). 

Needless to say, if you have seen the trailers hinting at Stark's cliff-side mansion collapse, the massive oil-rig explosion, the mid-air human monkey-barrel style plane rescue and the obscene amount of superfluous Iron Man clones all doing their fighting whilst flying thing, the innovation and execution of the films booming visual effects is simply jaw-dropping spectacular. 

The Verdict: In what can only be described as the best installment yet (and in saying that, hopefully the last to end on a well-deserved high note), Iron Man 3 delivers on every super-hero flick requirement. From imagination to excess, wit to star power, as far as entertainment goes this is the best option around; even if the plot and its quirky twist is as outlandish as Starks gizmos.  

Published: The Queanbeyan Age
Date of Publication: 10/05/2013

The storyline is suspenseful,, creative, and well put together.

The rock solid love between Tony and Pepper was sweet. Their relationship can clearly withstand a lot. It was a romantic ending, and I love that Pepper is the one who actually takes out the almost indestructible bad guy Aldrich Killian, after a knock em down drawn out Battle between Stark and Killian. The fireworks finale to the battle scene was perfect.

As usual, Colonel Rhodes has a significant side kick role to play in saving the day (and the President). They're both Iron Man, although very different personalities.

Iron Man 3 is a unique look at Tony Stark's character and how he is dealing with the post-traumatic stress from what occurred in The Avengers. Although this movie has less Iron Man and more Tony Stark, it is cool to see how he fights without the suit. The only weakness in the movie is the villain, who was the worst of the series of Iron Man films. Overall, this is an unexpected sequel for the the franchise and I enjoyed it.

It is nice to see a simple Iron Man movie without SHIELD or Avenger movie messing it up. Tony Stark is a dismissive jerk, and this time it comes back to haunt him. In a flashback to 1999, he rudely disregards an emerging enthusiastic scientist. Fast forward fourteen years that scientist reemerges as a handsome and successful businessman who soon finds himself at odds with Stark Industries. Amidst his business relationships, Tony Stark publicly challenges a global terrorist known as the Mandarin, who swiftly retaliates by targeting him. It is finally nice to see Tony humbled and undone by his reckless abrasive personality. In the course of events, he finds himself without a functional armored suit for much of the movie, and his better qualities shine through to save the day. We get to appreciate Tony Stark for the mechanical genius he is, not just a spoiled brat with infinite funds and firepower. The villain is good, but the showdown action scenes between him and Iron Man do not come through. There is too much going on at one time during the climax of the movie. It would be nice to distil this down to a clearer and more exciting finale.

Iron Man 3 was a lot of fun and it was a interesting take on the franchise. But is it any good?

Positives:
1. The characters; Again Robert Downey Jr. is awesome in this film, in fact he has a lot more humanity to his character this time around in this film. This movie focuses more on Tony Stark than Iron Man which might be a bad thing for some people who love their action, but I liked the direction it was going with his character. Gwyneth Paltrow is again great as Pepper Potts, I'm interested to see what direction they'll go with her character after her transformation into the Extremis. Don Cheadle was awesome as Rhodey, he is a lot more likable in this film than Iron Man 2. The rest of the cast is fine.

2. The action; this movie has the best action out of the whole trilogy. The action is filmed so well and it is a lot more fun. My favourite action scene is the finale as well as the airplane scene which was actually real and that definitely added more intensity and credibility to the scene. There is also some action scenes that involve Tony himself, such as the mansion scene where he takes out guards in a very entertaining way. Overall Iron Man 3 handles its action excellently.

3. The feel; this film does focus more on Tony Stark than Iron Man like I said, which might bore some people wanting more action but I honestly liked it especially the scenes he has with that kid. You honestly feel for Tony a lot more in this film and it adds more humanity to his character. This film seems to stray a bit more away from the typical superhero blockbuster extravaganza, which I loved.

Negatives:
1. The handling of The Mandarin. A lot of comic book fans are mad about this, I'm not a reader of comic books honestly but it did kind of bother me. Don't get me wrong the scene where its revealed that The Mandarin played by Ben Kingsley (who was great by the way) is just an actor was really funny and unexpected, but at the same time I felt it was a missed opportunity cause he could've potentially been a great villain. The real Mandarin turns out to be Aldrich Killian played by Guy Pearce which definitely did disappoint me.

2. I didn't care for Maya Hansen played by Rebecca Hall. Rebecca Hall is a good actress but her character was underdeveloped and when she does eventually die I didn't care to be honest. One more negative is that I didn't care for Killian's henchmen who were the people infected with the Extremis, I was like "meh" whenever they showed up.

Overall:
I had a lot of fun with Iron Man 3. It is not as good as the first movie but it is loads better than Iron Man 2. I liked the characters, the action and the overall tone of the film, but I definitely was let down by the villain and it could've been handled better.

Iron Man 3 is another great Marvel movie with impressive action sequences and plenty humor that will satisfy fans.

Whereas the first two Iron Man films become better with repeated viewings, I think Iron Man 3 is far less re-watchable.  Don't get me wrong, I'm one of the handful of defenders for the film, but the third entry just doesn't have the same spark as the first two films do.  Shane Black takes the film in a much darker direction.  That's fine, especially considering what Stark went through during the events of Avengers, but I think there was something missing in Iron Man 3, and I think the tone has a lot to do with that.

Considering the film begins with the Eiffel 65 classic Blue (da ba dee), Iron Man 3 is a bit of a departure from the previous Iron Man films.  Disappointingly, the film also doesn't contain any AC/DC songs or Ramin Djawadi's score.  It does however, supply a memorable score from Brian Tyler.  Besides that, all of the actors are back and the cast welcomes in Rebecca Hall, Guy Pearce, and Ben Kingsley in pivotal roles.  Tony and Pepper are now living together *happily* with Happy and Rhodey not too far away.

I understand people wanted the film to take a different approach after the mixed response to Iron Man 2, but this film was missing Jon Favreau's touch.  Not only did he not come back to direct the film, but Happy only gets a few scenes as he's hospitalized for the majority of the run time.  Don Cheadle has more action, but Tony Stark in Tennessee for the entire second act, I felt like I needed more Rhodey as well.  If anything else, the problem with Iron Man 3 is the writing.  Downey and Paltrow still have magnetic chemistry, but everything else feels different from the previous entries.

That brings me to the infamous Mandarin reveal.  I actually don't have as much of an issue with the direction they took Kingsley's character as everyone else does.  With that said, I can't say I wasn't at least a little disappointed that there was no real presence of the ten rings or anything that felt all that threatening.  I'm glad they decided to have a villain not in an Iron Man type suit to give Tony something different to fight, but as great as Guy Pearce is in other films, he just didn't do it for me as Aldrich Killian.

There is definitely something to the argument that this film needed more Iron Man.  Ty Simpkins plays Stark's tech sidekick back in Tennessee, and he's good, but I would have liked to see a little bit more Iron Man screen time.  But the counter argument to that would be that Tony Stark is just as entertaining as the metal head himself.  And that the insomniac Stark they were going for, kind of makes sense.  The central theme of 'demons' was an interesting take and probably the most necessary one at that particular stage in the universe. I can appreciate the gutsiness by the filmmakers to approach the character in this way, if only The Incredibles hadn't really done the exact same premise 9 years prior.

Overall, I really like Iron Man 3.  It's a much different take on Tony Stark and it was the next logical step for the Marvel Universe.  I just wish the writing had been more in the vein of the first two Iron Man's and not strayed too far away from what we love so much about this character.

Whatever Marvel movie followed The Avengers was going to struggle to overcome the scaling back that, in this franchise's very particular case, was unavoidable. Marvel movies, for better or worse, never take place in a vacuum, and for four years and five films, this studio was building toward something massive and unprecedented. And guess what-that movie didn't disappoint. So Iron Man 3 needed to somehow both pay deference to our journey so far within the Marvel world and also come down from a film about six superheroes to one about, well, just Iron Man. And guess what-it does just that.

Following the events of The Avengers, Tony Stark (Robert Downey, Jr.) has been asked to serve mankind as Iron Man only in matters intergalactic. His best friend, Jim Rhodes (Don Cheadle), now also known as the "Iron Patriot" is America's metallic protector against enemies foreign (as long as their of this world) and domestic.

So Tony holes up with his woman, Pepper Potts (Gwyneth Paltrow), and tinkers with his toys. The Iron Man suit must be better than ever if he's going to avoid another trip into a wormhole-an incident that induces panic attacks all this time later. With a new threat-The Mandarin (Ben Kingsley)-gleefully wreaking havoc across the world, it seems like Tony can sit this one out. But the forces of evil at play here hold a special connection to Stark, and before long, he's suiting up again.

For the first time in the history of this series, Jon Favreau stays in front of the camera exclusively-reprising his role as Happy, Tony's bodyguard. He opted not to take the reigns as director for a third time, passing those responsibilities to Kiss Kiss, Bang Bang helmer Shane Black. While Black doesn't have enough directorial credits to leave a strong, noticeable mark on the picture, Iron Man 3 doesn't really miss a beat, and he deserves a lot of credit for that.

Even more impressive than any stylistic tendencies at play here is the film's tone, which REALLY feels on point. Downey and Black have chemistry, and that chemistry made Kiss Kiss one of the last decade's most underrated comedies. Their collective quick wit is in abundance here; in fact, it's probably the film's greatest asset. There's a surprise near the midway point that's plays out so humorlessly that the rest of the film could have, I don't know, featured a deluge of incomprehensible action scenes aboard an abandoned and crumbling oil rig, and I'd still recommend it...

So about that conclusion...it's kind of a mess. The entirety of Iron Man 3 hinges on Stark's gadgets on working at key points. It's an incredibly frustrating crutch Black overuses whenever he wants to create some additional tension, and it's never worse than during the film's final 20 minutes. And the action during these sequences? Multiple Iron Man suits do battle, and we've seen it all before.

But the whimsy brought to this film through Black's pen and Downey's usual antics are more comforting than a warm blanket on a cold winter evening. This is the best Marvel film since Captain America: The First Avenger, and a reminder that superhero movies need not bear the weight of humankind's existence on its shoulders. Simply fighting a bad guy, when done right, is more than enough, as it is in Iron Man 3.

Iron Man one and two were great. They were both very interesting and told a story with excitement. Iron man 3 followed along and was also great. However this third movies has added new flares and surprises that Iron Man fans would enjoy.
 
Robert. Downey, Jr, manages to maintain the same smart, witty character now but with the added anxiety attack issue Tony Stark deals with. All the actors in this movie did an excellent job performing their roles and adding to the story. The film has managed to keep everything  seamlessly from Iron man one to three, while including what happened in The Avengers movie. Iron Man 3 had fewer events that took place and focused more on the character of Tony Stark; looking at how he lives his life and handles past events that have impacted him. Which in the end left you wanting for just a little bit more story line, unfortunately.
 
This movie has some great twists, for example: the villain who is portrayed on TV threatening the president is not the actual villain, it's just a cover. The real villain chooses a man (who is an actor) with a different ethnicity than regularly found in America. He stages the background of these videos to look like it's being shot in a different country as well. This makes all eyes look outside the country for this man, not inside America, keeping all the attention off the real villain. You get a surprise when Tony bursts through this man's bedroom door to discover that truth.
 
The film does a great job tricking the audience about what took place. The director has the viewers pause in shock about what just happened only to see a second later what actually happened. For example: Tony was dressed in this iron man suit and was saving people in the air who were free falling to their death. Tony goes and collects all these people in the air then safely drops them into the water. As Tony flys up from the water and over a bridge, he looks back momentary giving the audience a feeling of relief that he saved them all, then he gets hits hard by a bus and all the armor breaks into pieces. Shocked, moments later you see a screen where Tony has been directing this Iron Man drone to do all that work for him, he was never in the suit.
It was FANTASTIC, FUNNY and the final scene when all of his suits came to fight the Mandarin Army was EPIC.

I think I'm one of the only handful of people that actually really enjoyed this Iron Man adventure! I mean it was really good, everyone agreed, it was good up until the big twist 2/3rds through the movie and everyone's like, "Oh my god...this blows!" Overall I think it was a smart way to fit in with contemporary times in the ideas of what we see as the enemy to our face and behind our backs. that's pretty much the long and the short of it that's all I'm going to say about it. Let's go down to the rest of the movie.
   Iron Man 3 is the first entrance in the entire Iron Man franchise that hasn't been directed by Jon Favreau. This entry was directed and I think written by Shane Black who has written such awesome movies as lethal weapon 1 and 2, plus The Last Boy Scout he knows action and it shows. 
   Our story pretty much covers Iron Man right after the events of the Avengers he seems to not be sleeping, spending more time building more suits, suffering post traumatic stress disorder. All the while going on in the not so shadowy world there is a not-so-secret terror out there that calls himself The Mandarin (Ben Kingsley) who is a modern terrorist leader who will get in front of the camera now a days and pretty much go on about some sort of political rhetoric before threatening to do something harmful. Which over the course of the movie, he keeps his promises and there are some unfortunate events that do culminate in Iron Man and Colonel Rhoades played again by Don Cheadle joining forces as a buddy cop team pretty much to find the Mandarin.
   When they find the Mandarin the movie sort of does a Kansas City Shuffle; in the way that while everyone's looking right the movie went left. Again I repeat I liked the twist I really did and I really like the symbolism involving with the actual villain in the movie. I won't reveal who but I will say that it was a "Guy" and he tended to "Pierce" through my soul with his acting ability. I do feel that the story ended rather perfectly with what it had built up and and left up to debate like I think we'll be seeing Tony Stark is Iron Man here and there but maybe not as much as we would like to or probably could since Robert Downey Jr is technically a senior citizen.
   As the movie was over and even after watching it a second time I still feel that I really really enjoyed Iron Man 3. It's definitely head and shoulders above Iron Man 2, but just a eye line below Iron Man 1. I can only hand out recommendations like flyers for this. Fans of the Iron Man movies , comic book movie fans, action fans, Shane Black fans, and overall was just a really fun time and a really quick and enjoyable 2 hours that I'm gladly more than willing to put up again to watch a 3rd, 4th, or a 5th time.

Robert Downey, Jr is the best thing about Iron Man Three.  If this trilogy proves anything, it is that Downey's best natural gift, his mouth, hasn't worn out its welcome.  He has a rapid-fire speaking manner in which it takes you a second to register what he just said. Like Groucho Marx, his mouth is ready with a verbal gag almost before he can complete the thought.  He is really a wonderful comedian with the rare ability to mix the comedy with a certain amount of vulnerability.  This is a rare and precious gift at a time when most screenplays march their characters through wooden, pedestrian dialogue that only functions to move the characters from one plot development to another.  For Downey, it is such a unique gift that, while you're watching Iron Man Three, you realize that he alone is keeping the movie from becoming a crushing bore because by this point, he is keeping afloat a series that - hate to admit it - is running out of gas.

Iron Man Three is a well-made, skillful action movie - the special effects are convincing, some of the action scenes work, but they are at the service of a plot that is completely canned.  Here again is another story of a superhero battling and army of super-villains who want to take over the world while also dealing with domestic issues that no suit of iron will be able to cure.

The suit, for Stark, has become the same prison that it was for Batman, only in Stark's case he has become dependent on it.  How does one balance time with the girlfriend and saving the world?  He could do this because the public has fallen in love with War Machine, a new Iron Man occupied by Tony's pal James Rhodes (Don Cheadle).  This should leave Tony more time to be with girlfriend Pepper Potts (Gwyneth Paltrow) but she complains that he is spending all his time in the lab building new Iron Man suits.

Domestic bliss is only part of Stark's problem.  The latest threat to civilization is someone calling himself The Mandarin (Ben Kingsley), an impressive-looking cloaked figure with his own private army that has been committing acts of terrorism on every shore.  His private army seems invincible, they attack and walk away unscathed due to new developments in genetic recomposition -  yeah, apparently that's a thing.

Stark goes on television and makes an unbelievably stupid proclamation to The Mandarin and later finds his house under attack and Pepper missing.  That's a problem because, while the first movie allowed Tony and Pepper time to develop a sweet romance, this one keeps them apart for most of the film.  We're told how much Tony loves her (he narrates the story) but their scenes together are all too brief.

The presence of The Mandarin, you should know, is also all-too brief.  This character is to Iron Man what The Joker is to Batman, but there's a problem here: He's hardly in the movie.  You'll be alarmed when you realize that 95% of Ben Kingsley's performance was captured in the trailer and that the movie reveals a plot development that relegates him to a cameo role.  If you were looking for a big showdown between Downey and Kingsley, you're going to be sorely disappointed.

Much of the plot can't be revealed here without spoilers, suffice to say the movie is entertaining without being extraordinary.  You'll find that the action scenes get the job done, but if you're looking for world-class plot development, you'd be best look elsewhere.  Director Shane Black, the scribe responsible for the screenplays to The Last Boy Scout, The Last Action Hero and the Lethal Weapon movies injects a refreshing sense of humor onto a dead plot and wisely makes time for Robert Downey, Jr. to simply do what he does best, just talk.

The plot is the darkest and most complex yet in this trilogy while also the best crafted, the cast is excellent as ever (led by Robert Downey Jr's most confident rendition of the title character to date and supported by one surprising Ben Kingsley), both the action scenes and its humor are lightly improved thanks to Shane Black's direction and, lastly, the main villain is the best yet out of the three (even if the plot twist breaks completely with the essence of the original from the comics). In the end, "Iron Man 3", while not perfect, is the most confident and best crafted film of this now iconic character.

The theme of glowing people with special powers just does not feel in line with the first two movies, which are all about gimmicks and technology. The Iron Man is a hero because he is an ordinary man who has technology on his side, who as an intellectual inventor has technology which is better than that of his enemies, giving him the edge because of his smarts. Exchanging the enemy's technology for superpowers might at first seem like a clever attempt to avoid repetition of the same theme, but ultimately feels too alien to fit in an Iron Man movie, which is about self-made men and not mutants.

Kicking off Phase 2 of the MCU is Iron Man 3, the final and most underrated of the Iron Man films. Tony Stark is actually more than just the comic relief of the Avengers, and we actually see that there is much more to him. The twist in the movie was perfect, and while it angered many fans of the comic series, it was clever and unpredictable and the climax was the best of the trilogy. The twist did take away the darker tone of the movie, but it didn't take away the quality.

WHAT I LIKED: This is an odd mix of the amazing and the awkward, but mainly Iron Man 3 is full of the character stuff that makes Marvel films so great. Forget the rubbish of Iron Man 2, Tony Stark is developed perfectly and we really feel like we know him here. This is largely thanks to Robert Downey Jr being stripped back to basics, but it's also thanks to Shane Black's distinct style, humour and charm.
WHAT I DIDN'T LIKE: There are sadly a few things that you really can't ignore. I don't normally get hung up on plot if the thing flows; but hugely glaring holes and a baffling villain do sometimes make for one hell of a confusing narrative experience.
VERDICT: Iron Man 3 is arguably the best film in the Iron Man franchise. It's darker than the first, but still a whole lot of fun.

Although the Marvel films do have certain stylistic traits mandated by Disney/Marvel, they do a decent job of letting directors with distinctive styles leave their mark on the film.  You can feel Joss Whedon in "The Avengers" and James Gunn in "Guardians of the Galaxy", and you can definitely feel Shane Black here. Heavy Boots of Lead

As Tony Stark points out rather tellingly, "All nuance went out the window when the God with a hammer fell from the sky," or something to that effect. At least the writers and filmmakers knew they were going too far, pulling out all the stops, distracting us from the head- scratching plot by cramming Part Three with dizzying twists and out-of- nowhere characters and situations, all while flooding our senses with overcooked CGI and headache-inducing sound FX, and packing in so much smart-Alec dialogue that everyone started to sound like RD Jr.. Obligatory overkill. 

"So you can breathe fire?" Cheadle asks the real Mandarin. Yes, but apparently only once. You get an all-you-can-stomach smorgasbord of one-of-everything. You're senses will be subdued--overwhelmed--it's impossible to be bored, you get your money's worth of manic sights and pounding sounds. So why is it ultimately so unsatisfying? Since when is way too much not enough? This is the cinematic equivalent to over- indulging in franchised junk food. CGI obesity. High carb thrills. They'll soon have to supply cinemas with vomit bags. 

Still, I prefer Iron-Over-the-Top-Man better than Super-Off-the-Charts- Man. But I don't think anyone really knows how to pull off a well-rounded CGI-based movie yet. Well, there's always Avengers 2015 when Joss Whelon re-calibrates the signal-to-noise ratio, and hopefully restores some of the nuance needed to offset the onslaught of mindless action and sarcastic dialogue. Failing that, we can always hope for James Cameron's Aquaman.

"You can save only one, the President or Pepper Potts," Stark is informed. Wait! You're telling me they're not the same person? Nothing else was too ludicrous to pass up.

Better than the second but still not near the first, Iron Man 3 is as entertaining a film as you can get. This time around, the focus is back on Tony Stark, and Robert Downey Jr. once again delivers big time. The storyline this time is an interesting eone, and its nice to see a superhero movie where the lead has demons, and here Tony has much to deal with. Ben Kingsley is terrific and entertaining in the film, and though Guy Pearce's villain Aldrich Killian is a bit far-fetched, he's a talented actor who brings a good amount of spice to the film. Overall, Iron Man 3 is action-packed and marvelous fun and a great addition to the Marvel Cinematic Universe.

One day someone will discover inter-dimensional space travel. And so, we will be able to travel to a world where marvel actually make good films. Unfortunately,  we do not live in such a world. Iron man 3, whilst not the overall worst, may however be the most aggravating film the studio has ever produced. And thats a large call from a studio that makes, in general, far less superior superhero films than should be expected. To me this is the worst film in the iron man trilogy and for one very good reason: it could have been the best. In fact, the film had the potential to be the best the studio has ever produced.  But no, it squanders its talented cast and promising story on a reveal that feels cheap and lazy.  This film began rather promisingly, with the first scene a nice look at who Tony Stark was before certain events, setting the film up nicely. And then, the mandarin enters our screens portrayed by the all-powerful Ben Kingsley. And for the first time in a marvel film, I was actually captivated by the villain. The mandarin was (at least initially) a villain who had no motives other than to hurt tony stark because he could. Sir Ben Kingsley gave us a creepy, archaic and barbaric villain who put Tony Stark in actual danger. Gave him uncomfortable choices to make. Properly threatened him. When the film progresses however, you begin to suspect things are not always what they seem. The second act is a little dull and frankly lacks both action and suspense. Nonetheless,  the third act is by far the worst because it just proves how dumb marvel actually are. Ben Kingsley is NOT the mandarin. The spine tingling performance he gave was just a guy acting for someone else. Guy Pearce, who wants to turn everybody into weird green mucus monsters is the "real" villain. I mean, are you out of your mind, marvel? Guy pearce is a good actor, but he is NO Ben Kingsley. The best and actually first engaging villain, and he's not even the real villain. I mean, every bloody iron man villain is the same. Tony Stark offends them or does something they don't like, so want revenge; its extremely unoriginal and plays with only one-dimensional characters. This pissed me off very much so. The ending just feels anticlimactic and after the big reveal , nothing seems threatening. All is going to be fine. This movie actually made me question whether marvel actually make their movies dumb on purpose. Honestly, it would be like if in The Dark Knight, the Joker was actually just an actor. No, its actually The Penguin who's the real brains. Marvel you are now officially on my death list. As well as the moron who wrote this thing. I'm looking at you Shane Black. Just die

Ah, now here's a film that really seems to split its fan-base right down the middle, having not seen a comic book film stir up this much controversy since The Dark Knight Rises. Many might hate me for saying this, but I enjoyed Iron Man 3 for what it was and for the most part, I was thoroughly entertained throughout the entire film; once Blue (Da Ba Dee) by Eiffel 65 started playing over the Marvel and Paramount logos, the tone for this movie was instantly set and I knew I was in for something fun. After all, Iron Man 3 was easily a huge step-up from its generic predecessor, Iron Man 2. But there are many complaints regarding this film, and I'll address all of the major ones. First of all, I enjoyed how Tony Stark wasn't entirely his eccentric, carefree, narcissistic self in this film. It's clear that the events of The Avengers and the near-death experience in the wormhole has affected him severely and therefore, gives us a bit of a darker tone as well. To me, that showed that there's some actual depth and complexity to Tony Stark's character rather than him just simply being a complete narcissist, and that came off as very refreshing. As for Tony Stark having to go without his Iron Man suits for a huge chunk of the movie, I thought that was very interesting as well. It shows that Tony Stark can still be resourceful and useful even without his armor, proving that it is in fact the man that makes the suit and not vice versa after all. And while I didn't get quite as much Iron Man action as I wanted throughout the film, the final action scene certainly makes up for that. The humor was very witty and spot-on and for the most part, fits well into the film. The only problem I really have, and that everyone else seems to have, is the plot twist with "The Mandarin". The twist reveals to us that The Mandarin isn't really The Mandarin, simply rather a washed-up actor paid by Killian to give his crime syndicate a face, someone to blame everything on. Now from a film standpoint, I thought this was a brilliant twist for the film to make and if this were any smaller villain or a different movie entirely, this twist would've worked. But this is The Mandarin, Iron Man's arch nemesis, and doing something like that is really going to piss off a lot of loyal fans of the Iron Man comic book lore. Now because of that, I can certainly see why fans hate this film, and I don't blame them one bit. Imagine if The Joker in The Dark Knight turned out to be nothing but an actor while the real mastermind was someone else entirely; it would've pissed everyone off, and with good reason. Taking an iconic character and turning him into a simple plot device is basically like the filmmakers saying that they don't care about the character or the fans. And even though I don't know much about The Mandarin from the comics, this is nonetheless upsetting even to me because it ruins a beloved character that had the potential to be really amazing. Simply put, the twist works from a movie standpoint, but not from a comic book movie standpoint. And really, the whole film in general is like that: it works as a movie but not as a comic book movie or even an Iron Man movie. But it works well enough to keep me entertained and with these solo Marvel films, that's enough to ask for.
Shines at its best, but underdeveloped subtexts and plotholes leave it falling flat at its worst.

I rank Iron Man 3 below the laughs and thrills of the first entry, but above the overstuffed but still enjoyable second. It falls into the same trap that other superhero movies sometimes do; while the characters themselves are good, the plot itself is relatively uninteresting. Also, the mix of humor and seriousness isn't quite as balanced as the original Iron Man. There are scenes of intensity that are followed closely by clever/cheesy one liners, so you're never sure if you're supposed to take the events in the movie all that seriously or not. The drama is occasionally well handled (the climax) but sometimes unconvincing (Tony Stark having anxiety attacks caused by his near death experience in The Avengers). 

Not to say the movie is at all bad. For the most part, it's very entertaining. There are some laugh out loud moments throughout, and plenty of good visuals and action. Downey continues to prove that he's the perfect actor for the role of Tony Stark/Iron Man, and Paltrow is equally game as Pepper Potts. Guy Pearce makes for an OK villain, but he isn't particularly memorable.

Overall, Iron Man 3 is a solid movie. I wouldn't rank it amongst the 'best' superhero movies to ever come out, but it's definitely one of the better ones. A must see for fans of of the Marvel superhero universe, and a reserved recommendation for non-fans, as long as you don't expect anything truly great.

In what, to me, has become the Marvel standard (unfortunately, DC still wears the crown for Nolan's Dark Knight trilogy), Iron Man 3 is now the best third Marvel movie ever made.  And better than most second ones.  Stepping away from Favreau's direction was refreshing, and maybe that's the key here.  Shane Black's writing and direction of Robert Downey Jr is masterful.  While (spoiler alert), the twist with the Mandarin was silly (yet probably the best way to have the Manadarin in a feature film since he has always been a lame, yet prominent Iron Man character), introducing AIM the way they did and moving the story along through some great dramatic dialogue and storytelling, bumpered by flawless action scenes, proves that one can do a third movie in a franchise that isn't worthless.  The ending blew me away though, and I'm convinced there will never be an RDJ Iron Man solo sequel again.  We will see him in Avengers 2, I believe Guardians of the Galaxy and Avengers 3, but that's it.  And maybe even only as Tony Stark.  Just as team rosters changed frequently in the comic, so shall, I believe, we will see in the films.  Just as Nolan told the perfect Batman stories, RDJ IS Iron Man...and Tony Stark.  There was never anyone more perfectly suited to play them both.
A welcome and refreshing beginning to a new age of superheroes.

To me, this film seemed to have even less to do with the original Iron Man (and by the best film of the 'trilogy') than Iron Man 2 which barely achieved place mat status.  It certainly didn't do anything to advance the saga of Tony Stark nor did it add a sense of closure or continuity to the recent Avengers storyline. It did however do much more in destroying Pepper Potts as a credible character. 

As most Shane Black movies go, it involved Christmas... no wait, that's not fair.  It involved things that get shot and blow-up at Christmas.  Making a useless involvement of AIM, the Hydra-esque secret agency which could have been easily folded into the ongoing Marvel film or Television universe, the plot just sank. If the point of the movie was that Stark can survive through his wits, sarcasm and ingenuity, well we established that in the first movie, it's why he's Iron Man.  Since there are no plans to extend Iron Man into Phase Two or Phase Three in his own solo adventure, let's hope his involvement in the expanding Avengers universe fares far better than this.

Review In A Nutshell:

Iron Man 3 is set after the event in New York City and Tony Stark is suffering psychological problems from it, while at the same time, a new threat arises that calls himself the Mandarin.

The reception for this film was all over the spectrum, with some completely hating it and others unshakably praising it. After finally seeing it, long overdue and with enough distance from the hype, I can certainly say that this film is a blast. The film is certainly far from what the genre could offer but it impressed me enough to claim that this so far is the best from what Marvel/Disney/Paramount has produced.

The film's plot isn't the film's strength as it certainly includes elements everyone has seen before but it is Shane Black's direction that prevents this from being just another comic-book film. Black takes a predictable tale and spices it up with a couple minor twists, comedic and witty dialogue exchanges, and surprisingly deep character development to keep the audience on their toes and also become heavily invested with the titular character. It was truly fascinating exploring the psychological and emotional layers of Stark as that was something I never saw from the character before, in previous films, it was hard for me to relate or connect with the character because of the persona he creates for himself and previous directors never revealed any cracks for the audience to peek inside. Black was able to deliver this much depth while also maintaining that superficial wit that the character is known for, he may still speak like a smart ass but at least there is a reason for it.

The film contains a couple of antagonists, with each projecting a different level of threat. I was pleased with the way the writers handled the Mandarin as it definitely delivered something quite surprising. Aldrich Killian was a bit of a disappointment, not structurally as he did come off as quite a threat particularly during the third act, but as a person he just came off as a bit hollow and slightly cliché; but then again that is why they had the Mandarin as that character definitely delivered something that Aldrich Killian lacked.

The action set pieces were satisfying but nothing indulgent. It simply lacked the thrills that other action films seem to produce recently, but by the end of the film, I could forgive this film for not blowing me away in that regard as there were enough strong elements in the film, characters and dialogue, to maintain my engagement. I think I wouldn't be this harsh to the film's action if I hadn't seen Joss Whedon's The Avengers, particularly its last half hour.

The film's score, like the action, couldn't stand against what Alan Silvestri has delivered in The Avengers, but Iron Man 3's musical score sound very typical to the genre and does its job well enough that it added a bit of depth and flavour to a couple of the film's scenes.

The actors in this film did their roles very well, particularly Robert Downey Jr. and Ben Kingsley. Downey was able to show us shades of the character that we haven't seen before, showing a sense of humanity that has been lacking in a couple of his films lately; I am so glad to see the actor in top form again. Kingsley brought a sense of menace to the role, something that felt close to what he delivered in Jonathan Glazer's Sexy Beast, then showing a slight change in the middle of the second act which was certainly a surprise and had me loving his performance even more. Gwyneth Paltrow as Pepper Potts, I felt, was a little under used here as most of the film's heart is found in Tony Stark. She was great when she appears on screen, but on the third act her performance felt lifeless, I am not sure whether or not the blame goes towards the actress or the director as at the same time she is given very little to speak during this section of the film. Though I may not be a huge fan of his role in this film, but Guy Pearce certainly delivered a strong performance, but his presence during the first act of the film felt a little fake and over-done. Rebecca Hall's role was minor, which is a shame as she has proven herself in previous films that she is a worthy actress.

Iron Man 3 is a strong comic-book film, though a little underwhelming in its action, it does provide a sufficient amount of character development and witty dialogue that it elevates above its sibling films. Also, this is certainly a film I would be watching regularly during Christmas seasons.

Tony Starks is mentally fatigued from the whole concept of The Avengers, other universes, aliens, and being a savior for the world.  Unfortunately, during this mental state, a terrorist known as the Mandarin, starts launching terrorist initiatives.  Tony vows to stop the Mandarin, but he doesn't mentally appear up to the battle and losses his house and most of his weapons in the process.  Can Tony overcome his new nemesis?

"You'll never see me coming."

Shane Black, director of Kiss Kiss Bang Bang, and the upcoming Predator, Doc Savage, and Death Note, delivers Iron Man 3.  The storyline for this picture is entertaining and fun to watch unfold.  There did seem to be more Tony Stark than Iron Man in this picture and not as much action as the previous two films.  The acting was as you'd expect for the genre and the cast includes Robert Downey Jr., Guy Pearce, Don Cheadle, Gwyneth Paltrow, and Ben Kingsley.

I must say that I love superhero movies and have watched pretty much all of them. I was really excited about Iron Man 3 and got even more excited after watching the trailer. So I must say that I had very high expectations for this movie. I expected great special effects, exciting action sequences, good storyline and excellent acting.

However, I am sad to say that this movie did not meet my high expectations.This movie was not as epic as I expected.

1. In terms of pacing, the movie was slow at times, especially for the first hour or so.
2. The action sequences were excellent and well-executed but not as many as I expected.
3. The special effects were awesome and realistic.
4. The ending was very satisfying.

In summary, I like this movie but it did not meet my expectations that were buoyed by the hype surrounding the movie.

I was never a fan of the Iron Man comics, but how can you not loveRobert Downey Jr. as snarky inventor, billionaire, superhero Tony Stark? The story is nothing all that special, Guy Pearce is the villain, along with a very clever turn by Ben Kingsley as a middle eastern terrorist, but Downey is so good as the wise cracking Stark, that the film just crackles. Downey is particularly aided by terrific dialogue by director/co-writer Shane Black ("Last Boy Scout"/"Lethal Weapon"). Black previously directed Downey in the supremely underrated "Kiss Kiss, Bang Bang" which although not a hit, I would argue revitalized Downey's career, showing off his leading man chops following a string of personal problems. There's also a solid supporting cast that includes Gwyneth Paltrow, Don Cheadle, Jon Favreau, Paul Bettany. I also found it pretty funny that two usually villainous character actors, William Sadler and Miguel Ferrer, were cast as the president and vice president of the United States. Overall, this film belongs to Downey and director Black. For me, it's more Black that came away from this film as the hero, directing and writing a successful major blockbuster. I really hope he get free reign like he did with "Kiss Kiss, Bang Bang". Seriously, all of ya'll should go watch that film right now.

Iron Man + Lethal Weapon = Iron Man 3 until halfway through the film. The premise of the film and the first half of the film is a superhero cinematic perfection. The chemistry between the characters were enjoyable and the plot line reminded me of Lethal Weapon 2. There was a nice mix of weight and lightness until the halfway mark. The story took a twist which in many cases work but ended up pissing off the fan base. Then, the film becomes a normal action movie with great action scenes and no emotion as well as no character redemption. It was an upgrade over Iron Man 2 and I thought Shane Black did a creative job doing a superhero Lethal Weapon hybrid. It just ran out of steam at the end. 2.5 stars. It's a serviceable film in total but not the best Iron Man film by any standard

The biggest problem that people have with this movie seems to be an awful representation of the main villain. This particular aspect is bad in its own right, but, honestly, I think this movie's problem go far beyond that specific gripe that people have. My problem with this failure of film is its defective writing, poor conceptualization, dull characters, inconsistent tone, lack of intelligence and thematic integrity. Iron Failure 3 is as superficial and trivial as you can get. Depth in this movie is non-existent. Character motivation is flat. The characters themselves are poorly written cardboard figures with no personality. 

There is no stakes and no tension. Everything is paint by numbers and generic. As for the controversial miss-handling of the main villain, which many defenders of this movie have described as an act of brilliancy, because it had some imaginary message behind it, I have my opinion on that.

The only hidden message that this movie gave us, is that Shane Black should never again direct another comic book movie. I guess people think about that meaningless plot-point too much. Iron Man 3 is not a Dark Knight, when you can write a book about all the subliminal meanings behind the film. Iron Man 3 is a cookie-cuter, generic, uninventive schlock. Maybe the idea behind this "hidden message" looked good in a concept, but the execution is what kills any potential for this to be taken seriously. It's like with the Prometheus, which had great ideas, but the execution of those ideas was flat and dull. Iron Man 3 was even worse than that. 

I am fully aware, as a few other people with actual brain cells, that this cheap option was not executed well and it didn't had the abstract meaning which maybe it originally intended to have.

Iron Man 3 is generic, cheesy, poorly written mess with no actual depth. If Shane Black, who is definitely not someone who has brilliant writing and directing skills, intended to mock the perception of terrorism in society, he would have an entire film dedicated on exploration of that. But he's too dumb and generic to actually make something good out of that concept. People are giving simply some generic excuses for the fact that Shane Black did very poor execution with the story and the conceptuality of the film (which it didn't really had). 

Shane Black is the one who thinks that tasteless one-liners and dull action is more important than sophistication and inventiveness. He never wrote or direct a movie that really has something intellectually to offer. He wrote Last Action Hero, after all. That's says a lot about his style.?

I LOVED this movie.

EPIC action sequences - Action sequences were the BOMB. I loved it. It had decent, well choreographed action where many things were happening simultaneously and still made sense. It was great.

It had strong character development - He was influenced from the events of the Avengers. That's why he had PTSD. It was a whole and complete movie, and that and Cap2 are the movies in the MCU that I can feel happy watching over and over again, because they don't leave loose ends, have a bit of everything and they are completely exciting.?

I have a few thoughts on the villain. Filmmakers often think that a villain who can sympathize with the audiences is the best. Most do that too. But Iron Man 3 was bold. It's decision to go with a hate- able villain and actually pulling it off is a feat onto itself.

I mean, his motivations were simple itself. Sell Extremis and gain money. The way he pulled it off and the filmmakers displayed it was remarkable. He created a fake persona, the Mandarin, and enabled him to create war and terror. This in turn would create widespread panic among this US, and coupled with the killing of the US president and literally controlling USA when it's vice president came to power, would cause the nation to crumble and allow him to gain a profit.

Killian was counting on the media to stare at the Mandarin's face value, and blowing it out of proportion, when he was charge the whole time.

This was a very clever jab by Shane Black to the current hype created by the media by over blowing every threat, and turning every attack into a frenzy. 

Not to mention that it was a clever way of bringing back the post industrialist complex of Iron Man 1 and 2. The whole trilogy literally has a common and consistent theme. The post industrialist complex of evil businessmen and CEO's who could threaten the world, largely due to their immeasurable greed for money and power.

The message may not have been as clear as, say, the TDK trilogy, but it still stands, and its very popular in the contemporary world.

Overall, this movie was amazing. I loved it. Best of the trilogy, and I hope that Iron Man returns.

Featuring loud sound effects and a huge amount of superb action, fight and special effects scenes with the help on an ensemble casts Iron Man 3 is the best and the most memorable Marvel movie since The Avengers, The Amazing Spider Man and Captain America: The Winter Soldier. Iron Man 3 takes place after the events of The Avengers where Tony Stark is trying to live a peaceful life. But soon his life is now facing a new threat when a mysterious enemy known as the "Mandarin" is creating an army of extremis super soldiers and when he also learns of the kidnapping of his girlfriend Pepper Pots he must save the world and his girl from the danger that he is facing. I so love Iron Man 3 and I'm serious about it to be honest and it is better than Iron Man 1 and 2 any other Marvel movies like Thor 1 and 2 and lastly The Hulk films. One of the highlights of this movie is that the film itself is full of magnificent special and CGI effects and I'm serious the effects in this film are both satisfying and infinitely awesome. I love all of the effects in this film and my personal favorite special effect in this movie is the design of the extremis effects and all of the effects on the extremis soldiers are pure cool I mean it check out the scene where one of the extremis people blow up in the Chinese theater where Stark's friend and body guard gets critically injured or the scene where we see one of the people who becomes an extremis soldier gets her arm regenerated but the effects are well used in the finale of the movie. The other things I like about this film is that the movie has loads of non stop action scenes that are fun and extremely memorable(The first encounter with the extremis soldier of Mandarin, the attack at the bar and the outstanding finale where Iron Man calls all of his suits to fight Mandarin's army oh and I almost forgot to mention the best part of the film where Iron Man saves one of the President's friends in the airplane and the fight scene with Mandarin and Iron Man is superbly fun). While the last things I like about this film is that the movie's soundtrack is amazing and I love Brian Tyler's score for this film a lot the soundtrack is super cool in this film a lot. Now the acting is superbly awesome in this film. All of the returning casts including the new ones did a fantastic job with their performances in the film a lot. Robert Downey Junior did an amazing job with his performance as Iron Man once again and he seems to have exceed his performance in this film even though his character isn't as comical as before. Same can be said to Gwyneth Paltrow and Jon Favreau who both reprise their roles as Pepper Pots and Happy Hogan. Ty Simpkins did an amazing job with his performance as Iron Man's kid friend and I love his performance in this film outside of the Insidious movies. And Rebecca Hall and Guy Pearce did an amazing job with their performances as Maya and the main antagonist and Iron Man's worst enemy the Mandarin. But the most hilarious actor who delivers one of the most hilarious performances in movie history is Ben Kingsley who's character Trevor Slatery is super funny in the film if you thought that he was the bad guy in the first half because of his voice and menacing look then his performance in the last half became extremely hilarious which is what I consider as the funniest plot twists in movie history. As much as I love the suits, there was just too much of them in this movie, but understandably since there were so many of those darn fire-emitting-super-soldier-type henchmen guys, but the final showdown was just too busy. Iron Man 3 was by no means Marvel's best addition to the franchise, but it was enjoyably witty and entertainingly action-packed, much like its predecessors (not so much part 2, of course). If you want to nitpick there are a few, short instances where "Iron Man 3" is a little rough around the edges but it's an incredibly satisfying chapter in the "Iron Man" series and a thrilling action film. Not only do we get to see the characters we've come to really love back once again, with Robert Downey Jr. as Tony Stark/Iron Man, Gwyneth Paltrow as Pepper Potts and Don Cheadle as James Rodes/War Machine, but there are some neat additions to the franchise as well. This third film is actually an improvement on the second one, with a villain that really feels like he is able to not only match wits with Tony Stark but is able to match him when it comes to the firepower department as well. The Mandarin (Ben Kingsley) feels like a genuine threat not only to Iron Man but also to War Machine (who is rebranded as "Iron Patriot" early in the film) and there are some genuine moments of tension where you really don't know how the good guys are going to get out of the pickle they've found themselves in.
The special effects are excellent and there are some scenes that are quite spectacular throughout. A particular standout is the film's climax where there are so many characters and effects flying around that it will take you several viewing to be able to even start grasping every element. Once again the action and thrills are well balanced with some good comedy, including a one-joke character that comes in towards the middle of the film and leaves quickly, but not before delivering a hilarious joke that fits so perfectly in this Marvel character's universe that it will be remembered for years (If you're trying to figure out who I'm referring to, let's just say it's a big fan of Tony Stark).
Everything inside the film's story feels like it's a step up from where the franchise started. The technology in the Iron Man suit is more advanced and dazzling, the characters are richer and face odds that are greater, the villain is more threatening and the action is cranked up to anew level between the scenes of drama. There are also some good twists and turns throughout the story that will really catch you by surprise too. While you will probably have your doubts on whether or not it's possible for certain characters to actually die since they're part of such a big franchise, there are at the end of the film some big changes to the Iron Man series that will leave you a bit emotional and have you cheering for more too. Once again, make sure you stick all the way to the end of the credits of the film (for a quick scene that is a lot of fun) and watch out for a cameo from Stan Lee that's very funny. The 3-D effects are quite good (there are a couple of scenes where ash is falling all around the characters that's particularly well done) and during the action sequences there is debris flying everywhere so on the big screen it's a ton of fun to see. "Iron Man 3" is exactly what you want in a three-quel (if that's a word) to a successful and satisfying franchise and it really delivers. (3-D theatrical version on the big screen, May 16, 2013)

Every action scene excites and entertains from the jaw dropping air rescue to the explosive finale, and not forgetting the total obliteration of Starks house! Iron Man 3 packs more action than it's predecessors, and is far better than the poor second film. This third instalment, and the start of Avengers Phase 2, sees Stark suffering from panic attacks and a lack of sleep because of the wormhole in New York. Robert Downey Jr. is on fine form as expected and Tony Stark is far more vulnerable this time, it seems all these big budget movies like to make their protagonists weak (Skyfall, Dark Knight Rises), so they can build themselves and fight back, although it's getting a bit tiresome now. Iron Man takes one hell of a beating, and there's not much reliance on the suit this time around so Iron Man 3 proves you don't need a suit to be a hero. Gwyneth Paltrow is undoubtedly one of the most talented and hottest actresses, and seeing her fight and use the suit is absolutely brilliant. Don Cheadle is in nearly every action scene, he's awesome and very funny too, yet again the talent is being used in all departments. Rebecca Hall is fantastic, and her characters holds a twist that will take you by surprise, and she has great chemistry with Potts. Guy Pearce is a convincing bad guy, he's merciless and cunning, but doesn't stand as high as Loki who is still the bad guy to beat. Sir Ben Kingsley's performance is something to behold, I'm not giving away any spoilers but I guaranteed you'll be so shocked, and amused. This is knockout entertainment, and one of the best Superhero movies in recent memory.

Iron Man 3 is one of my favorite films of 2013. I'm a huge fan of the first Iron Man. It's one of my favorite superhero movies. Robert Downey, Jr. was fantastic as Tony Stark and as Iron Man. Iron Man 2 is a very good sequel although nowhere near as great as the first film. Of course, everybody knows that Marvel's The Avengers is my all-time favorite superhero movie. IM3 totally exceeded my expectations and is my favorite of the Iron Man trilogy. 

Iron Man 3 involves Tony Stark, now with post-traumatic stress disorder after the events of The Avengers, as he's now bitten in the ass due to his obsession of building all these Iron Man suits and using them save the world and him being the biggest asshole in the world back in 1999, on New Year's Eve. So he has to figure out how to fix this shit all by himself while coming face-to-face with the evil terrorist, The Mandarin. 

When I heard Jon Favreau was stepping down as director, I was worried this was gonna suck. But then I heard Shane Black was gonna be directing the film and co-writing the script with Drew Pearce. I cheered. Shane Black wrote Lethal Weapon 1 and 2, The Monster Squad, The Last Boy Scout, Last Action Hero, The Long Kiss Goodnight, and Kiss Kiss Bang Bang (which he also directed). With a résumé as flawless as that, there was no way I was gonna be let down by Iron Man 3. 

The story, the tightly-written characters, the witty dialogue, the direction, and of course, the action and effects, are done the most well here and there was more conflict this time around. This was a very personal story for Tony Stark and it works perfectly. Shane Black went very deep into Tony's psyche and conjured up something special not only for Iron Man fanboys, but for common moviegoers as well. 

We're reminded that while Tony is a genius billionaire alcoholic playboy philanthropist, he's anything but perfect. He's made several mistakes during his past just like any other human being has. His greatest strength is his intelligence, not saving the world. His greatest achievement is his relationship with Pepper Potts, not building the Iron Man suits. Even without the suit, Tony is still Iron Man. The man makes the suit, not the other way around. This tone works brilliantly in this film. 

Now, let's get to the action. The action sequences and special effects are fucking awesometacular. I was vastly entertained by them. Not only does this film have the best action of the three Iron Man films, but also has the best climax. Now, some people would say that the climax is basically Transformers 4, but come on, you all know it was awesome. The effects are very impressive, even without the work of Industrial Light & Magic onboard. The action is shot beautifully by cinematographer John Toll, and Shane Black never lets the story overshadow the action or let the action overshadow the story, and he never wastes the audience's time. 

Now, I gotta talk about this real quick: the villain is first believed to be the Mandarin, but over an hour into the movie, it's revealed that the Mandarin was a persona created by Aldrich Killian of AIM and the person portraying the Mandarin is drunken British actor Trevor Slattery, played by Ben Kingsley. All the fanboys were pissed off at this twist. If you're not a fan of the twist, that's fine. I have no problem. I have read some issues of Iron Man. The ones I read had the Mandarin. He sucks. He's just an irritating racially-insensitive Wang Chung stereotype, and he's supposed to be Iron Man's arch-nemesis? Yeah, there's no way in hell you're gonna get me to buy that. The twist was ingenious, and the film gets better beyond that. As a plus, the twist provides social commentary on modern-day terrorists that works very well. 

The performances are absolutely fantastic. Robert Downey, Jr. doesn't play Tony Stark/Iron Man. He IS Tony Stark/Iron Man. He absolutely fucking owns this role, and this would have to be Downey's best performance of his career. Gwyneth Paltrow is given a much bigger role this time around as Pepper Potts and she's given more to do, and she's more than just a damsel in distress. Guy Pearce does a wonderful job playing Aldrich Killian. Killian is a great villain whose motives make perfect sense. Don Cheadle does a great job as Rhodey and is given a lot more to do. 

FINAL SCORE: 10/10 

I was more than satisfied with this movie. I loved how Shane Black took Tony Stark back to his roots, demonstrating his genius and never at all derailing from the story at hand. The action sequences are brilliantly filmed, the music score by Brian Tyler was just wonderful and outstanding, the villains are the best in this trilogy of films, the twist was ingenious and unpredictable, and Robert Downey, Jr. is Iron Man indeed. I loved this film. It's definitely on my top 15 of the year.

Overall the movie feels more like a comedy than a superhero, which disappointed me as I didn't expect this much humor in a superhero movie. The action is still fun to watch, especially its final act. The most controversial part of the movie is its twist which made a mockery of Iron Man's main nemesis in the comics, the Mandarin.
Conclusion: Iron Man 3 is a disappointing start to Phase Two, bogged down by its excessive humor and unnecessary plot twist.
Rating: 3/5

Iron Man 3 is probably one of the better films in the Marvel Cinematic Universe (next to The Avengers, of course).  The reason being is that it decides to take the focus away from Iron Man and more on the psyche of Tony Stark.  The Mandarin isn't his only nemesis in this film, but he also has to face his biggest challenge of all: his sudden sense of mortality.  This is not the same Tony that we've seen in the first two films and The Avengers.  This is a Tony Stark who is afraid that he is an inferior man without the Iron Man suit and feels like he isn't strong enough to protect the only people that he cares deeply for.  While I understand why so many people are upset with how The Mandarin is portrayed in this film, let me start off by saying that fans of the source material have every right to be upset... but ONLY the fans of the source material.  Take it from a guy who has never read any of the comic books... just pretend for a moment that you have no knowledge of a comic series that these films are based on.  Just go in and watch the movie... judge it for yourself.  That's exactly what I did, and as far as The Mandarin goes, yeah, I will admit, I was a little bummed, but not to the extreme like the comic fans were.  The final battle during the film's climax is hands down the absolute best battle / fight scenes out of all the Iron Man films, bar none! The best Marvel movie since the original "Iron Man," Shane Black's "Three" uses Jungian psychology as a framework for superhero action and actually makes it work. There's a real evolution of Stark as a character, as well as the Iron Man concept itself (where do potential sequels go from here?) that your average Hollywood franchise would be utterly terrified of approaching. Downey Jr. and Paltrow continue to deepen the relationship between Tony and Pepper as well; it feels genuine and unique (a stark-- no pun intended-- contrast to the generic lovey-dovey nonsense of Thor and Jane Foster). The late attempt to transform Pepper into a super-powered fighter is rather silly though (A female character being forcibly given super-abilities by the villain is not empowering, no matter how many cool backflip kicks she does). Cheadle, Pearce, and Kingsley are great. Rebecca Hall is underused.

"Iron Man Three" has some plotting issues (like watching Tony go through the motions of investigating the Chinese Theater explosion even though we, as an audience, already know what's going on), but it contains the most jaw-dropping plot twist I've seen in years. The main villains motivations are also a bit ho-hum, and the moment with the kid's workshop at the end is a bit twee (even as his early interactions with Tony were refreshingly absent of sap), but these are somewhat minor issues in an otherwise well-constructed narrative.

I think what's really worth celebrating is the unique, character-driven nature of the action-sequences in the film, such as the Barrel-of-Monkeys bit (which seriously gets my heart thumping), and the delightful hardware-tools mansion siege. Even during the bigger, explosion-heavy CGI-fests (like the final battle), we get some the interesting mind-controlled-armor mechanics that lend a creativity to the action beyond simple punching and shooting.

Iron Man 3 was considered to be a disappointment by many, but I myself loved it.  In a post-Avengers world, Tony Stark is dealing with post traumatic stress, but when a new villain known as the Mandarin threatens America, Tony must rise to the challenge.

Though Iron Man 3 is a departure from what Marvel movies have set up in the past, I believe that the darkness in this movie is perfect following the Avengers.  The film has a darker mood to it that makes everything feel a little more real, in that Christopher Nolan feel.

The dialogue in this movie was also great.  Some may find Stark's jokes cheesy, but I think for a damaged character like him, it works.

One complaint that I've heard about the movie is how there's less Iron Man and more Tony Stark, similar to the Bruce Wayne Batman ratio in The Dark Knight Rises.  For Iron Man 3, which is the story of Tony Stark following The Avengers, the lack of Iron Man makes sense.

In conclusion, I believe that Iron Man 3 is exactly what Marvel intends when making a superhero film: to chronicle one of their characters.  And I believe that Iron Man 3 is the strongest Marvel stand alone movie.

Iron Man 3 is a film that I feel was let down by the fantastic marketing. The outstanding trailers for this movie promised us a dark story that delved into Tony Starks anxiety after the events of the first Avengers while he went up against his most challenging villain yet. However what we got is a mediocre, forgettable and goofy movie. Just like in all Marvel movies the acting is brilliant Robert Downey Jr steals the show as usual. Gwenyth Paltrow, Guy Pearce, Don Cheadle, Ben Kingsley, Rebecca Hall and Jon Favreau are all excellent. There are some really good jokes in the movie, the bit where Tony Stark calls the little kid a pussy is really funny. The action is phenomenal. The mansion raid scene while very illogical is great as is the plane rescue scene. The final action sequence is brilliant unlike in the previous two movies. I also think the last 40 minutes of the film are ridiculously entertaining. The Mandarin is set up brilliantly I love the creepy news footage and he's very menacing in these bits. I also feel the anxiety is handled excellently in the first half. However this film has a lot of bad. The biggest and most obvious one is the handling of the Mandarin. As I've said the Mandarin is handled fantastically at the start of the movie however after he blows up his house and pushes him to breaking point, Tony Stark invades the mandarins mansion with homemade weapons, he reaches the Mandarins bedroom and he comes out of the toilet having just taken a huge shit and we get the stupid reveal that Ben Kingsley is infant a British actor who only portrays the mandarin on the tv and instead Guy Pearce is infact the Mandarin. This is a really stupid move as they had brilliantly set up Ben Kingsley and then just did a huge cop out and made him an annoying drunk druggie actor. Another problem is Guy Pearce as Aldrich Killian or the mandarin, he has a terrible motivation, infact it's the same as Snydrome from the Incredibles or Electro from the Amazing Spiderman 2. While the extremist idea could have worked really well it doesn't and it's laughably hilarious to see Guy Pearce breath fire. Another huge problem is that after Happy Hogan is injured in an explosion caused by 'the Mandarin' Tony gives out his address on the news and the Mandarin attacks in helicopters and blow up the house. However Tony does nothing to stop them or set up any defense when he has around forty suits under his house ready to defend him. I love the plane scene and it's the best part of the film however it is revealed at the end that Tony Stark wasn't in the suit as a lorry hits the suit when he is flying away and it breaks into a million pieces. This brings up two problems as it cheapens the scene as all Tony was doing was sitting in a room and just controlling through a head set. Also in the first movie the Iron Man Armour took a tank missile and didn't break, in the second movie it took Whiplash's electric whips and didn't break, in the Avengers it took Thor's Lightning and didn't break, in this movie a lorry breaks it. All the suits in this film are terrible it's like they're made out of tissues and paper plates. They also fake our Pepper dying which is just pointless. Ty Simpkins (the kid from Insidious) is in the film and while he's good he fairly pointless and slows down the movie. I also think Killian is a terrible villain, he's very unthreatening and has awful motivation. I also hate how when he finally gets a bit badass and yells 'I am the mandarin' he's immediately hit off screen and killed a by Pepper. Tony has anxiety T the start of the movie however it's suddenly forgotten about half way through. I also feel they tried to wrap up this film to neatly, with Iron Man blowing up all his suits and being able to fix himself. You see Shane Black directed this film well however it feels like he wanted to make a action comedy movie with Robert Downey Jr and then had to put Iron Man in it, because as a buddy comedy movie this works, as an Iron Man movie it doesn't. The Unfortunately there are a lot of flaws and it's definatley one of the weakest marvel movies. I will say it's better than Iron Man 2 and Thor the Dark World, but it's nowhere near perfect. However it made.a lot of money. See it if you want but there are so many Marvel movies better than it. B-
