Iron Man - brilliant, Iron Man 2 and 3 - both ok. Robert Downey rescues the film from mediocrity as he did with Iron Man 2. For me, the film switched from silly to serious too often and aimed at a family audience as opposed to an action movie audience.

Man, it's a terrible shame that Tony Stark didn't call in some help from Bruce Banner, played once again by Edward Norton, as Norton has always said that he wants to fight Gandhi. ...You know, because the antagonist in this is played by Ben Kingsley... and Norton's character in "Fight Club" said he would fight Gandhi. Sorry for that, people, it's just that I can't help but think of "Fight Club" when I see a Shane Black film and think about how much "Kiss Kiss Bang Bang" was like a Chuck Palahniuk story, which is actually pretty amazing, because as good as a "Kiss Kiss Bang Bang" is, it came out so long ago that it's hard to remember. Yeah, I should be a little careful with statements like, "when I see a Shane Black film...", because "a" could insinuate that there is, in fact, more than one Shane Black film in existence. Oh hey, now there is, because "Kiss Kiss Bang Bang" was one of Robert Downey, Jr.'s big comeback films, thus, Downey owes Black a favor, which is cool for me, because Black has been missed for a reason since 2005, even though I do miss Jon Favreau as director. Hey, he understood that he had to pass the torch, because as "Iron Man 2" told us, he was getting rusty with his handling of this subject matter... or at least that's what's being said by everyone other than me, that one jerk who actually liked "Iron Man 2" better than the first "Iron Man"... and thought Chris Nolan's "Dark Knight" series was underwhelming, up until "The Dark Knight Rises"... and thinks that "Watchmen" is a masterpiece. Yeah, I've never been the person you need to look to if you want recommendations for a superhero film, but I can at least agree with the consensus that the first "Iron Man" is better than this installment, which is decent, sure, but messy.

As a writer, Shane Black really knew what he was doing with the tongue-in-cheek "Kiss Kiss Bang Bang", but here, whether it be the fault of co-writer Drew Pearce or whatever, his writing style not only doesn't work as well as it probably should, but feels under-inspired in certain areas, carrying a certain cheesiness, both within the sometimes obnoxiously forced humor, and within the often near-aggravatingly histrionic drama, neither of which are consistent enough with the cheesiness to prevent tonal inconsistencies that break what tension there is with much too much fluff. They don't even break out the Marvel Studios title card before giving you a little peak at Tony Stark's lab getting destroyed, in slow-motion, to a deeply dramatic score and a narrating Stark quoting a profound proverb regarding man's downfall by his own mistakes, before humorously questioning the proverb and losing his train of thought, until he is finally silenced by Eiffel 65's "Blue (Da Ba Dee)", and those first few seconds of this film, alone, really warn you that this isn't going to be nearly as serious as it probably should be, and as sure as sunshine, tonal unevenness that still isn't inconsistent enough to keep fluffiness from being way too prominent really undercuts much of the bite of this film, much like pacing unevenness. Even pacing is all over the place, with developmental lapses marking heights in the questionability of the rushing that is generally simply obnoxious, while the 130-minute runtime is largely reached through repetitious excesses in material that get to be so overblown that they don't simply taint storytelling with aimlessness, but bloat the overall narrative concept. None of the "Iron Man" installments have been all that tight, but this story concept feels particularly bloated something fierce, with too many subplots and story branches to keep up with without focal inconsistencies, even on paper, without tonal and pacing inconsistencies found in the execution of a convolutedly overblown story that isn't even refreshing. This film may hit some flaws not usually hit by superhero opuses this high in profile so severely, but outside of that and a few more flattering storytelling elements, there's nothing new here, and such shameless genericism and overall predictability make what is conceptually an important addition in the mythology for this film series feel barely consequential. I was expecting, or at least hoping for anything from a rewarding blockbuster to the best "Iron Man" installment yet, but in the end, the film is nothing short of a mess that never loses decency, but slips, little by little, under the weight of misguided incoherencies and a degree of inconsequentiality, until the final product sputters out as, of all things, the most underwhelming "Iron Man" yet. Of course, even though it falls short of substance, as sheer blockbuster fluff, this film delivers as thoroughly entertaining, complete with some pretty impressive style.

Just like most every other effort by one of everyone's favorite formulaic blockbuster score composers, Brian Tyler, this film's original soundtrack is highly convention, but it's still pretty strong, with a lively sweep, punctuated by subtly gripping intensity that sustains entertainment value, while John Toll's cinematography further supplements the liveliness, not necessarily with as much of the rich coloration and crisp lighting that they keep showing off in the well-polished marketing campaigns, but with some very stylish camera tricks that immerse, at least as technically impressive, even if they're not nearly as impressive as the visual effects. If nothing else meets expectations, it is, of course, the amazingly well-rendered and delightfully creative effects that, this time around, grace the screen most of the time, and dazzle consistently, especially in the heat of action whose staging ranges from thoroughly fun in its grandness, to tensely tight, but never falls short on uniquely entertaining dynamics, anchored by remarkable technical proficiency. Style is strong and technicality is absolutely outstanding, just as I expected, even if substance isn't what I was hoping for, and yet, even then, it's not like substance is completely misguided. I find it difficult to fully stress just how overblown this film's story concept is, yet there are plenty of intriguing fluffy, dramatic and even thematic elements for Drew Pearce's and Shane Black's script to do injustice with unevenness in pacing, focus and tone, in addition to conventions and cheesiness, until admittedly delivering on some colorful dialogue and humor, if not engaging dramatic elements that are brought to life by Black's direction. Tone is all over the place, but it's sold pretty effectively by lively, when not reasonably intense storytelling, so for every mistake Black makes, he shows yet more potential as a blockbuster filmmaker, although that's not to say that the onscreen blockbuster stars in this film do just as solid, if not a more solid job of selling things the best that they can. If nothing else outside of the aesthetic blockbuster material has been consistent in delivering, it's been the acting, and even with acting material's being particularly thinned out in this particularly dramatically underwhelming installment in the "Iron Man" saga, the strong performances remain, with just about everyone across the board offering chemistry and charisma, especially leading man Robert Downey, Jr., who steals the show as surely as he always does with an effortless display of sizable charm and subtle layers that bring more depth to the iconic Tony Stark character than this script. This film is a whole lot more superficial than I was expecting or hoping it would be, and even with that taken out of account, the many flaws here challenge the memorability of the final product, but the patient will no doubt find a thoroughly fun blockbuster and reasonably worthy third installment in the "Iron Man" film series, no matter how much it falls short of its potential.

When it's time to retire the suit once again, exhausting inconsistencies in tone, pacing and focus to the telling of a convolutedly overblown, yet still generic and superficial story concept wear down the final product, until it collapses, not just into underwhelmingness, but as the relative weakest installment in the "Iron Man" series thus far, though not so deeply that sharp scoring and photography, amazing effects and action, reasonably colorful writing and charismatic acting - especially from Robert Downey, Jr., of course - aren't enough to drive "Iron Man 3" as a fun, if highly flawed blockbuster.

Robert Downey Jr. is back as Tony Stark in Iron Man 3; that's pretty much it. In this over-hyped, underwhelmed sequel to Iron man 2, which I would like to forget (i'm looking at you as well, Spiderman 3), Marvel decided to cash in on the franchise's popularity and deliver a decent movie, at best. Firstly, the plot is just out-right ridiculous. There are a lot of action movies that have a C plot at most in order to push the story forward to give the movie chances to showcase action scenes for the audience. Now while Iron Man 3 does this, the plot was so unbearable that I wasn't even interested in seeing the action scenes. The plot was all over the place with no sense of coherency and it was just uninteresting. The main villain? No sense of motivation, anti-climactic and was just a face for the movie to have a final confrontation and ridiculous 'love triangle', if you want to call it that. And I feel like secondary character barely got more than 5 minutes screen time; they were just there to push the plot (or lack thereof) along.
	 What marvel tried to do was show another side of the Tony's character; a more human side. They could have done very well with this, especially considering that  lot of comics have source material, which is another reason why the lackluster effort was so disappointing. He's suffering from PTSD from the events of the Avenger's movie, which again, is a great idea, but it's handled so sub-par. You have a few moments where he gets anxiety attacks but it's never really explored or dealt with. They do the whole hollywood blockbluster sense of 'hero is needed and ergo, gets over issues off screen'. In the comics, it's riveting how Tony gets over his issues; you see despite his arrogance, he's actually vulnerable and it's just a front because the world's always watching him. Ever since the end of Iron man when he announced it, i've never gotten this feeling. This brings me to the performances. Downey owns iron man; that's pretty much a given, minus a few really forced scenes here and there and Palthrow as Pepper, well, they could have done worse. The only person who has great screen time and wasn't given enough was Cheadle; he had comedic timing and some really great one liners. I will admit though, that there were a few moments where Downey and Palthrow's screen time was sweet and found a way to show Stark's vulnerability as previously mentioned, even if a little. 
	The action, was a mixed bag. Already having discussed the reason for plot, I found myself not looking forward to them at all, but then in my surprise, actually enjoying them when they were played out. But by the time I did, they were finished, minus the final confrontation, which even I have to admit was really entertaining. The special effects were okay but I saw no need for 3D, as usual, since it was just served as a gimmick and ticket price increase. But that's pretty much it; no substance, no special moment that i'll remember or take from this movie. After movies like the Nolan's Batman franchise, Amazing Spiderman and the Avenger's for crying out loud, standards for superhero movies are sky high, and Iron man 3 just didn't soar at all. This is going to be down the middle though; Iron Man 3 was one of those movies that either you really liked or you really hated, depending on your taste, so I don't expect everyone to agree, but it's just my opinion.

Yes, I am one of the very few people that didn't like the first two "Iron Man" movies. Now, there's even a third one.

What is very disingenuous about "Iron Man 3" is that it kept referring to last year's summer blockbuster film, "The Avengers", throughout its narrative. Yet when faced with a global terrorist, none of those other superhero characters were anywhere to the found. The storytellers can explain it all they want, but in the end, the reason given was a copout. Flaw #1.

Its finale contains one of the biggest deus ex machina ever conceived in an action film. Spoiler ahead: While it makes for a grand finale, the sudden appearance of Tony Stark's hidden arsenal is a cheat. Flaw #2.

Shall I go on? I better not. Needless to say, I still found this to be the best of the three. Its villain played by Guy Pearce is not just cracking a whip and Gwyneth Paltrow's Pepper Potts gets to do other things. Others may also like it just as long as one doesn't pay too much attention to the logic of its story - as one can poke many holes into it.

In a lot of ways this is Iron Man 2 done correctly. And in a lot of ways it's also The Dark Knight Rises done correctly. What do I mean by that? Well, in the first Iron Man sequel we tried to explore just how Tony Stark copes with being a hero and going through intense trauma. Unfortunately he dealt with it by regressing back to the jerk that he was at the beginning of the original Iron Man. This made him unlikable. Here, though, we get a bit more likable and believable version of that. Robert Downey Jr. is still very good in his role, fully immersing himself into the role of Tony Stark. You buy that this is a man that has too much burden on his shoulders, but who still tries to do what is best for the ones he loves.

We also get to see him struggling with the fact that being a hero takes its toll on you, like we saw in The Dark Knight Rises. I like this version better, because it's a bit more logical progression instead of hitting us from the blindside. And by the end of the film we achieve closure in a much more realistic way than we did in Nolan's version. Furthermore, the special effects are still some of the best you've ever seen, the visual style is very pleasing and it has some of that same humour that made the first one so enjoyable.

Unfortunately this movie falters when it comes to its villains and side characters. Well, new side characters, because the returning ones are still more than serviceable. Gwyneth Paltrow is still an excellent Petter Potts. The villains however, are both bland and unlikable. They start pretty intriguing and you can see the potential, but then the movie decides to zick when it should zack, and the whole cardhouse comes crumbling down. I also absolutely loathed the kid sidekick that they decided to throw in, seemingly at the last minute. Yes, a kid sidekick, in a Marvel movie. You can see the problem, right?

Nevertheless, this is not a bad film, in the end. It's not nowhere near as good as the first one, but it's better than the second one. If you have liked the Marvel movies so far, you won't be disappointed.

(***1/2)  Iron Man 3 is almost as good as the first one.  In fact it might be as good as the first one if the first one hadn't been first.  Also the last line of Iron Man 1 was simply one of the best ways to close a movie in recent years.  This one exceeds it, however, in great effects and also in witty dialogue.  It's amazing that they were able to keep an already 3-movie character so fresh with a simple simultaneous breakdown of his psychology and technology.

In Iron Man 3, Tony Stark faces a brilliant researcher who he sort of brushed off in the past, only to have it bite him in the butt years later.  This is one of my gripes in the film, because the villain is almost a carbon copy of Jim Carrey's Riddler.  While this is a far superior movie overall, the theme is a bit tired.  Also in this movie, Tony's repertoire of suits gets dealt a massive blow, making him essentially have to work from scratch for much of the film (reminiscent of his cave time in Iron Man 1).  Oh yeah, and he's had a sudden onset of panic attacks stemming from the events of The Avengers, which is one of the greatest parts of this movie.  It realistically portrays how shell-shocked a normal human would be when thrown into a situation of gods and alternate dimensions.

Some of the special effects are astounding in this film.  The most notable in my mind being a scene where he rescues falling people.  This scene was filmed with real actors instead of CGI, which makes it grab your attention all the more and glue you to the seat edge.

The plot of Iron Man 3 may not be incredibly original, but the way individual scenes unfold is almost always unexpected, which makes a movie way more entertaining.  Overall, this movie surprised me with just how good a third film can be, and speaks to the increasing quality of sequels in our growing age of information where bad reviews reach the public instantly.  Hopefully this trend continues.

Iron Man 3 is not directed by Jon Favreau- who helmed the first Iron Man 2 movies. The director is Shane Black, and trust me, you can feel the change. The tone of this movie feels so different from the first two movies. And even though the movie is quite an improvement over the second movie, it does not come even an inch close to the first one.
 The flaws in this movie are way too many, but so are the strengths. First of all, Robert Downey Jr. as Tony Stark/Iron Man is as good as ever. Just like The Dark Knight Rises, we see more of Tony Stark and less of Iron Man. At a point, Stark has to start from scratch and do things- at this point he is almost alone and helpless. You get to see the genius side of Stark which was not shown one bit in the second movie.
 Coming to the villains, we have Guy Pearce as Aldrich Killian- who reminded me of Jim Carrey as The Riddler. As the movie progressed, I could still not make up my mind about how I felt about his character. The fault lies not in the acting, but the villian feels too much of a cartoon character, rather than a comic book hero villian.
 Ben Kingsley knocks it out of the park as The Mandarin. Or does he? Mandarin's story arch is probably the most controversial thing about this movie- some might love, some might hate it, and some might even be a bit confused as to what they feel about it. Its been roughly a year since the movie came out, and I still cannot confirm completely how I feel about this movie. 
 The movie also feels really inconsistent at times. There are a lot of times when there is a lot of things packed into one and you don't really know what the movie really wants to convey. 
 This movie is definitely the most serious and darkest of all the Iron Man movies- Black takes a route which is quite different from the previous two installments.
 All in all, if you are a comic book hero fan, or just a casual movie watcher, Iron Man could be the movie which satisfies you every bit, or it could be the movie whose existence is questioned by you. It's definitely not a movie which will appeal to all>

This is the final entry in the Iron Man trilogy, which follows events take place directly after The Avengers.  The story is good, but it just doesn't seem to have the flare of the previous two entries.  It is good to see all the returning characters, but they do feel a little played down compared to the over the topness of how they have been portrayed before.  The action is just a frantic as you would expect, but there does seem to be a bit of a lack of Iron Man himself, and when he does appear you do feel a little cheated.  All in all, this is still a good movie, but it does have a completely different feel from the previous two entries, and it is nowhere as comic book as we have come to expect from the franchise.  Also, there are a lot of references to the The Avengers, and if you haven't seen the movie, one feels that you are missing out on some of the more important nuances in the storyline.

Top 10 Things about Iron Man 3

10. Visuals: as always, STUNNING

9. Man I'd give my left breast for Stark tech!!

8. The script restricts logical decisions. In TN with no wallet, Jarvis offline, don't wanna involve Pepper or Rhodes. Coulson dead. Can't call Fury, Hawkeye or Widow because they're not in the script. smh It's a shame too. Even a nameless SHIELD agent would've been better than that FUCKING KID!!!

7. The Axis of EVIL! Political satire! I love it! Ben Kingsley's Osama bin Laden...I mean Mandarin was WOOOOOOW

6. Pepper's red hair may be gone but at least they didn't nerf her. By the 3rd installment of Star Wars, all Padme did was blink and cry.

5. What is the airspeed of those damn suits?? They got from Malibu to Miami in like 30 minutes didn't they??? And parts of the suit are powered and work independently? by anyone?!?! You'd think they'd have retina scan security. I'm just saying...

4. It never occurred to me one could get PTSD when they won the fight. Tony didn't even have PTSD when he had an ARC reactor installed in his chest to save him from the shrapnel in his heart that he got from being blown out of the funvee and held captive in a cave. He already didn't like to be handed things, now panic attacks. It's like "how neurotic can we make Tony Stark. We need something on the level of Spiderman whiny". Thank goodness he's the star of the movie and will always win because if he ever lost, he'd eat a repulsor blast.

3. No more script writing for Shane Black or Drew Pearce PLEASE! Arm chair psychology kids. There is no coming back from that.

2. For a former playboy, Tony is more communicative and committed to his relationship than I thought he'd be. No learning curve in his committed relationship attempt. He's all in. The first time. 

1. I LIKED THE BUNNY! I would've sprayed it with Tony's cologne and been found cuddling with it when Tony wasn't home. I guess I'm goofy like that *kanye shrug*

One star for the skydiving. 1/2 for Iron Patriot. 1/2 star for Guy Pearce and 1/2 for Don Cheadle. He grew on me. 1/2 star for the BUNNY!!

Now *this* was a surprisingly good movie. They found a way to allow the best actor in all the Marvel series to act through his makeup, by leaving the main iron plate off his face for 95% of the movie. What a concept! This movie not only redeemed its predecessor in Iron Man 2, but set a pretty high bar for the other Marvel post-Avengers movies. They also managed to wrap the story in case Downey Jr is finally getting tired of this role. It had plenty of creative twists to keep me interested, and didn't fall into the patronizing toy-sales trap that some of the other Marvel films have gotten into. Grade A-.

Iron Man 3 is so different from the first two. Shane Black tells a darker Iron Man story that is a worthy follow up to the Avengers. The character of Tony Stark is the most likable here, trying to fight his enemies and protect the ones he loves. This is in part thanks to a young boy who teams up with him, and Stark sees a little of himself in the child. The movie is pretty well written, with funny one liners throughout, though some of the dialogue comes off as cheesy. The Mandarin is a formidable antagonist, and despite the controversial turn his character takes, it was an unexpected twist that adds to the film. The climax is a lot of fun, and the story conclusively ends for Iron Man. The action is awesome and Robert Downey Jr. is as talented as ever. The villains felt a bit underdeveloped and the plot was flimsy at times. The action is fantastic but the storytelling is a bit oddly structured. However, we get to see that it is the man that makes the suit in this third Iron Man. Iron Man 3 gets 3.5/5 (B).
